entries.rootAnalysis: הֵיכָל occurs 80 times. As loanword, it emphasizes grandeur. It can mean: (1) palace (1 Ki 21:1), (2) temple main hall (1 Ki 6:3, 5, 17), (3) heavenly temple (Ps 11:4). The temple הֵיכָל was the Holy Place, before the Most Holy.
entries.otUsage: הֵיכָל describes: (1) Solomon's temple (1 Ki 6), (2) heavenly temple (Ps 11:4, Mic 1:2), (3) royal palace (1 Ki 21:1), (4) temple in prophetic visions (Ezek 41). YHWH speaks from His הֵיכָל - whether earthly or heavenly.

keyPassages.hebrew: יְהוָה בְּהֵיכַל קָדְשׁוֹ יְהוָה בַּשָּׁמַיִם כִּסְאוֹ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH is in His holy temple; YHWH's throne is in heaven.

keyPassages.hebrew: אַרְבָּעִים בָּאַמָּה הָיָה הַבָּיִת הוּא הַהֵיכָל
keyPassages.significance: Forty cubits was the house, that is, the temple/nave.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיהוָה בְּהֵיכַל קָדְשׁוֹ הַס מִפָּנָיו כָּל־הָאָרֶץ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH is in His holy temple; let all earth be silent before Him.

entries.theologicalSignificance: הֵיכָל emphasizes the royal dignity of worship. YHWH is King; His temple is His palace. The earthly temple reflected heavenly reality. Appropriate response to הֵיכָל is reverent silence and awe.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus cleansed the temple (ναός, John 2:19-21). His body was the true temple. Believers are God's temple (1 Cor 3:16). Heaven's temple opened (Rev 11:19, 15:5). Final state needs no temple (Rev 21:22).

entries.title: Tent
entries.summary: אֹהֶל is the tent - the portable dwelling that preceded the temple. The אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד (Tent of Meeting) was where God met His people. Tent imagery emphasizes God's willingness to journey with Israel.
entries.ancientContext: Tents were primary dwellings for semi-nomadic peoples. The tabernacle's tent structure suited Israel's wilderness journey. Unlike permanent temples, it moved with the people. Tent-dwelling gods were rare in the ancient Near East.
entries.rootAnalysis: אֹהֶל occurs 345 times. The verb אָהַל means 'to tent, dwell in tents.' אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד (Tent of Meeting) occurs 130+ times. The tent was covered by the מִשְׁכָּן (dwelling/tabernacle).
entries.otUsage: אֹהֶל describes: (1) ordinary dwellings (Gen 4:20), (2) Tent of Meeting (Exod 33:7), (3) tabernacle structure (Exod 26), (4) poetic reference to dwelling (Ps 15:1, 91:10). Israel transitioned from tents to houses in Canaan, yet tent imagery persisted.

keyPassages.significance: He called it the Tent of Meeting - pre-tabernacle.
You shall set up the tabernacle of the Tent of Meeting.
LORD, who may dwell in your tent?

entries.theologicalSignificance: אֹהֶל shows God's humility and mobility. He didn't demand a palace but dwelt in a tent. The Tent of Meeting emphasized accessibility - any Israelite could inquire there. Tent language continued even after the temple was built.
entries.ntConnection: The Word 'tabernacled' (ἐσκήνωσεν) among us (John 1:14 - tent imagery). God will 'tent' with humanity (Rev 21:3). Our earthly tent will be replaced with heavenly dwelling (2 Cor 5:1-4). Feast of Tabernacles recalled tent-dwelling.

entries.title: Appointed Time/Meeting
entries.summary: מוֹעֵד is the appointed time or place - where and when God meets His people. The 'Tent of Meeting' (אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד) was place of divine appointment. The מוֹעֲדִים (festivals) were appointed times for sacred assembly.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient calendars marked sacred times. Israel's מוֹעֲדִים were fixed by YHWH, not negotiable with priests. The Tent of Meeting was appointment place - God met there at set times. Sacred space and time intersected.
entries.rootAnalysis: מוֹעֵד occurs 223 times. From יָעַד 'to appoint, designate.' It means: (1) appointed time (Gen 18:14), (2) appointed place (Josh 8:14), (3) assembly (Num 16:2), (4) sacred season/feast (Lev 23:2). The festivals are 'YHWH's מוֹעֲדִים.'
entries.otUsage: מוֹעֵד describes: (1) Tent of Meeting (Exod 27:21), (2) sacred festivals (Lev 23:2, 4, 37, 44), (3) appointed time (Gen 18:14, 21:2), (4) assembly/congregation (Ps 74:8). The מוֹעֲדִים structured Israel's annual worship calendar.

keyPassages.significance: These are my appointed feasts, holy convocations.

keyPassages.hebrew: פֶּתַח אֹהֶל־מוֹעֵד לִפְנֵי יְהוָה אֲשֶׁר אִוָּעֵד לָכֶם שָׁמָּה
keyPassages.significance: At the door of the Tent of Meeting where I will meet you.
They burned all the meeting places of God.

entries.theologicalSignificance: מוֹעֵד teaches that God is accessible at appointed times and places. The מוֹעֲדִים were not random but divinely ordered. Sacred calendar formed Israel's identity. Meeting with God was scheduled appointment, not chance encounter.
entries.ntConnection: Christ is our Passover (1 Cor 5:7). The festivals find fulfillment in Christ. Believers gather for appointed meetings (Heb 10:25). The Lord will come at the appointed time (Gal 4:4, Eph 1:10). New creation has no need of sun/moon for times.

entries.title: Mercy Seat
entries.summary: כַּפֹּרֶת is the mercy seat - the golden lid of the ark of the covenant where atonement was made. On Yom Kippur, the high priest sprinkled blood on the כַּפֹּרֶת, where God promised to meet Israel.
entries.ancientContext: The כַּפֹּרֶת was solid gold, with cherubim at each end, wings overshadowing it. It covered the tablets in the ark. YHWH appeared 'upon' (עַל) or 'between' (בֵּין) the cherubim. It was the most sacred object in Israel.
entries.rootAnalysis: כַּפֹּרֶת occurs 27 times. From כָּפַר 'to cover, atone.' The name emphasizes its atoning function. LXX translates ἱλαστήριον (propitiation). The כַּפֹּרֶת was where atonement was visibly applied.
entries.otUsage: כַּפֹּרֶת describes: (1) ark's golden lid (Exod 25:17-22), (2) place of meeting (Exod 25:22), (3) Yom Kippur blood application (Lev 16:14-15), (4) God's presence location (Num 7:89). Only high priest, once yearly, approached the כַּפֹּרֶת.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְנוֹעַדְתִּי לְךָ שָׁם וְדִבַּרְתִּי אִתְּךָ מֵעַל הַכַּפֹּרֶת
keyPassages.significance: I will meet with you and speak with you from above the mercy seat.
He shall sprinkle with his finger on the mercy seat.
From between the two cherubim, from above the mercy seat.

entries.theologicalSignificance: כַּפֹּרֶת was the meeting point between holy God and sinful people. Blood on the כַּפֹּרֶת covered sin. The ark's contents (law) met the mercy seat - justice met mercy. This was the place of grace.
entries.ntConnection: Christ is our ἱλαστήριον (Rom 3:25 - propitiation/mercy seat). His blood satisfies divine justice. We approach boldly through His blood (Heb 4:16, 10:19-22). The real mercy seat is in heaven (Heb 9:5, 24).

entries.title: Heart
entries.summary: לֵב is the heart - center of thought, will, and emotion. Unlike modern usage focusing on feelings, the Hebrew heart is primarily the mind and will. God examines hearts; transformation begins there.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient peoples located thought in various organs. For Hebrews, the לֵב was the center of the whole inner person - intellect, emotion, will. It was hidden from others but open to God. Heart-knowledge was personal, experiential.
entries.rootAnalysis: לֵב occurs 854 times, with variant לֵבָב 252 times. It refers to the inner person comprehensively. 'Heart' thinks (Deut 8:5), plans (Prov 16:9), feels (1 Sam 1:8), and wills (Exod 35:5). Uncircumcised heart resists God.
entries.otUsage: לֵב describes: (1) thinking/understanding (1 Ki 3:9), (2) intention/will (Exod 35:21), (3) emotion (Ps 4:7), (4) conscience (1 Sam 24:6), (5) the whole person (Prov 4:23). God tests hearts (Jer 17:10). A new heart is needed (Ezek 36:26).

keyPassages.significance: Love YHWH your God with all your heart.
The heart is deceitful above all things.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְנָתַתִּי לָכֶם לֵב חָדָשׁ וְרוּחַ חֲדָשָׁה
keyPassages.significance: I will give you a new heart and new spirit.

entries.theologicalSignificance: לֵב teaches that God cares about the inner person. External conformity without heart change is worthless. The fundamental human problem is the heart; the solution is heart transformation by God's Spirit.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus taught that sin comes from the heart (Matt 15:18-19). The greatest command involves the heart (Matt 22:37). Believing is with the heart (Rom 10:9-10). God writes on hearts (2 Cor 3:3). Pure hearts see God (Matt 5:8).

entries.title: Flesh
entries.summary: בָּשָׂר is flesh - the physical, bodily aspect of human existence. It emphasizes vulnerability, mortality, and creatureliness. All flesh is grass; flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom. Yet God became flesh.
entries.ancientContext: בָּשָׂר could mean meat (food), skin, body, or humanity as a whole. 'All flesh' (כָּל בָּשָׂר) meant all living creatures or all humanity. Flesh contrasted with spirit, emphasizing weakness versus divine power.
entries.rootAnalysis: בָּשָׂר occurs 270 times. It refers to: (1) meat/food (Gen 9:4), (2) human body (Gen 2:21), (3) blood relatives ('my flesh', Gen 37:27), (4) humanity ('all flesh', Gen 6:12), (5) human weakness (Ps 78:39).
entries.otUsage: בָּשָׂר describes: (1) physical body (Gen 2:23), (2) kinship (Gen 29:14), (3) all living creatures (Gen 6:17), (4) human frailty (Isa 40:6), (5) mortality (Ps 56:5). 'One flesh' describes marriage union (Gen 2:24). Flesh is weak but not inherently evil.

keyPassages.significance: They shall become one flesh - marriage.
All flesh is grass - human transience.
I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh.

entries.theologicalSignificance: בָּשָׂר teaches human creatureliness without denigrating materiality. Flesh is mortal and weak but not evil. God created flesh and will redeem it. The contrast with spirit shows human need for divine empowerment.
entries.ntConnection: The Word became flesh (John 1:14 σάρξ). Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom (1 Cor 15:50). The flesh wars against the Spirit (Gal 5:17). Yet resurrection includes the body (1 Cor 15).

entries.title: Hand
entries.summary: יָד is the hand - instrument of action and symbol of power. YHWH's hand delivers, creates, and sustains. Human hands work, bless, and worship. The hand represents agency and authority.
entries.ancientContext: Hands were crucial in ancient economies - craftsmanship, agriculture, warfare. 'Laying on hands' conveyed blessing or commissioning. 'Stretching out the hand' meant taking action. God's hand was His powerful intervention.
entries.rootAnalysis: יָד occurs over 1600 times - one of Hebrew's most common nouns. Beyond the physical appendage, it means: power (Deut 8:17), possession ('in his hand'), direction ('on the right hand'), and agency.
entries.otUsage: יָד describes: (1) physical hand (Gen 3:22), (2) God's power (Exod 15:6), (3) possession (Gen 39:4), (4) violence ('lift hand against', 2 Sam 18:28), (5) blessing (Gen 48:14). 'By a mighty hand' recalls exodus. 'Into your hand' means under your authority.

keyPassages.significance: Your right hand, O YHWH, glorious in power.
Bind them as a sign on your hand.
Even there your hand shall lead me.

entries.theologicalSignificance: יָד shows God as actor in history. His hand creates (Isa 48:13), delivers (Exod 13:9), and holds (Ps 37:24). Human hands should serve God. 'Clean hands' means moral purity (Ps 24:4). Hands raise in worship.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus healed with hands (Mark 6:5). He is at God's right hand (Acts 2:33). No one snatches from His hand (John 10:28). Hands lay on for commissioning (Acts 6:6). Lift holy hands in prayer (1 Tim 2:8).

entries.title: Face/Presence
entries.summary: פָּנִים is the face - the expression of identity and attitude. Seeking God's face means seeking His presence. God's face shining brings blessing; His face hidden brings judgment. The face reveals the person.
entries.ancientContext: Face-to-face communication was primary. Turning one's face meant attention; hiding the face meant rejection. 'Before the face of' meant 'in the presence of.' Ancient rulers were approached face to face by suppliants.
entries.rootAnalysis: פָּנִים occurs over 2100 times - always plural in form but often singular in meaning. From פָּנָה 'to turn.' It means: face (literal), presence, surface ('face of the waters'), and anterior ('before').
entries.otUsage: פָּנִים describes: (1) human face (Gen 3:19), (2) divine presence (Exod 33:14-15), (3) favor ('lift up face', Num 6:26), (4) anger ('his face fell', Gen 4:5), (5) surface (Gen 1:2). 'Face to face' describes intimate encounter (Num 12:8).

keyPassages.significance: YHWH make His face shine upon you - Aaronic blessing.
Your face, YHWH, I will seek.
You cannot see my face - divine holiness.

entries.theologicalSignificance: פָּנִים teaches that relationship with God is personal. Seeking His face is worship's goal. Hidden face means judgment. Moses spoke 'face to face' uniquely. Ultimate blessing is seeing God's face (Ps 17:15).
entries.ntConnection: We see God's glory in Christ's face (2 Cor 4:6). We will see Him face to face (1 Cor 13:12). Believers behold with unveiled face (2 Cor 3:18). Angels see the Father's face (Matt 18:10).

entries.title: Eye
entries.summary: עַיִן is the eye - organ of sight and window to the soul. Eyes can be good or evil, opened or closed. God's eyes see all; human eyes reveal character. 'Finding favor in eyes' means gaining approval.
entries.ancientContext: Eyes were considered windows to the inner person. The 'evil eye' was widely feared. Blinding enemies neutralized them. 'Eyes of YHWH' meant His omniscient observation. 'Eye for eye' was proportional justice.
entries.rootAnalysis: עַיִן occurs 887 times. Homonym עַיִן also means 'spring/fountain' (Gen 16:7) - perhaps from the eye's watery nature. Eyes see, desire, express emotion, and symbolize moral perception.
entries.otUsage: עַיִן describes: (1) physical sight (Gen 3:7), (2) favor ('in the eyes of', Gen 6:8), (3) appearance (Lev 13:55), (4) moral vision (Prov 22:9 - 'good eye'), (5) divine omniscience (2 Chr 16:9). Opened eyes see spiritual reality (2 Ki 6:17).

keyPassages.significance: The eyes of both were opened - fall's consequence.
As eyes of servants look to their master.
The eyes of YHWH range throughout the earth.

entries.theologicalSignificance: עַיִן shows that sight is more than physical - it's moral and spiritual. What we look at shapes us. God sees all; nothing is hidden. Opening eyes to see God's truth is enlightenment; blindness is judgment.
entries.ntConnection: The eye is body's lamp (Matt 6:22-23). Jesus opened blind eyes (John 9). Scales fell from Paul's eyes (Acts 9:18). 'Evil eye' idiom continues (Mark 7:22). We shall see Him as He is (1 John 3:2).

entries.title: Ear
entries.summary: אֹזֶן is the ear - organ of hearing and obedience. To 'incline the ear' means to listen attentively. God's ear is not heavy; He hears His people. Ear-piercing marked willing servitude. Uncircumcised ears resist God's word.
entries.ancientContext: In oral cultures, ears were crucial. Ear-piercing marked permanent servitude (Exod 21:6). Anointing the ear consecrated priests (Lev 8:23). 'Ears to hear' was a call to spiritual receptivity.
entries.rootAnalysis: אֹזֶן occurs 187 times. The verb אָזַן means 'to listen, give ear.' The hiphil הֶאֱזִין is 'to hear attentively.' 'Ear' appears in idioms: 'uncover the ear' (reveal), 'heavy ears' (spiritually deaf).
entries.otUsage: אֹזֶן describes: (1) physical ear (Exod 21:6), (2) attention (Ps 17:6), (3) obedience (Jer 7:24), (4) revelation (1 Sam 9:15 - 'uncover the ear'), (5) God's hearing (Ps 10:17). 'Ears of YHWH' emphasizes His attentiveness to prayer.

keyPassages.significance: You have opened/dug my ears - attentive obedience.
Lord YHWH opened my ear - servant's obedience.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֹזֶן שֹׁמַעַת וְעַיִן רֹאָה יְהוָה עָשָׂה גַם־שְׁנֵיהֶם
keyPassages.significance: The hearing ear and seeing eye - YHWH made both.

entries.theologicalSignificance: אֹזֶן connects hearing and obeying. God speaks; humans must hear. Spiritual deafness is judgment. The opened ear marks the faithful servant. Hearing leads to response. God's ear toward us models prayer confidence.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus said 'He who has ears, let him hear' (Matt 11:15). Faith comes by hearing (Rom 10:17). Ears 'tickled' want pleasing words (2 Tim 4:3). The Spirit speaks to churches (Rev 2-3).

entries.title: Blood
entries.summary: דָּם is blood - the life-substance that atones for sin. 'The life is in the blood' (Lev 17:11). Blood crying from ground demanded justice. Sacrificial blood covered sin. Shedding innocent blood was gravest offense.
entries.ancientContext: Blood represented life across ancient cultures. Israel uniquely prohibited blood consumption. Blood manipulation was central to sacrifice. Bloodguilt polluted the land. Blood covenant was the most solemn commitment.
entries.rootAnalysis: דָּם occurs 360 times. Etymology possibly related to דָּמָה 'to be like' (blood is red like wine). 'Blood' appears in compounds: אִישׁ דָּמִים (man of blood), דְּמֵי נָקִי (innocent blood).
entries.otUsage: דָּם describes: (1) life-force (Gen 9:4, Lev 17:11), (2) violence/murder (Gen 4:10), (3) sacrificial blood (Exod 12:7, Lev 1:5), (4) bloodguilt (2 Sam 1:16), (5) wine metaphor (Gen 49:11). Blood must be treated reverently as sacred to God.

keyPassages.significance: The life of the flesh is in the blood - sacrificial basis.

keyPassages.hebrew: קוֹל דְּמֵי אָחִיךָ צֹעֲקִים אֵלַי מִן־הָאֲדָמָה
keyPassages.significance: Your brother's blood cries from the ground.
When I see the blood, I will pass over you.

entries.theologicalSignificance: דָּם teaches that life belongs to God. Blood's sanctity underlies sacrifice. Sin requires blood; atonement comes through blood. The prohibition against consuming blood honored life's sacredness. Blood cries for justice or mercy.
entries.ntConnection: Christ's blood establishes new covenant (Matt 26:28). We are justified by His blood (Rom 5:9). His blood cleanses from sin (1 John 1:7). Without blood shedding, no forgiveness (Heb 9:22). Blood speaks better than Abel's (Heb 12:24).

entries.title: Head
entries.summary: רֹאשׁ is the head - both body part and position of leadership. As anatomical term, it's the top. As metaphor, it means chief, leader, or beginning. Heads are anointed, bowed, lifted, or covered.
entries.ancientContext: The head was the most honored body part, seat of life. Anointing the head consecrated. 'Head of' meant leader. Bowing the head showed submission. Covering the head indicated mourning or shame.
entries.rootAnalysis: רֹאשׁ occurs 598 times. Uses include: (1) anatomical head, (2) leader/chief (Deut 1:15), (3) top/summit (Gen 11:4), (4) beginning (Exod 12:2), (5) total ('heads' counted). רֵאשִׁית (firstfruit, beginning) derives from this root.
entries.otUsage: רֹאשׁ describes: (1) body part (Gen 3:15), (2) leadership (Judg 11:11), (3) top of mountain (Exod 19:20), (4) first in time (Exod 12:2), (5) source of river (Gen 2:10). Oil on head anoints (Ps 23:5). Bowed head shows worship or grief.

keyPassages.significance: He shall crush your head - protoevangelium.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֶבֶן מָאֲסוּ הַבּוֹנִים הָיְתָה לְרֹאשׁ פִּנָּה
keyPassages.significance: The rejected stone became head of the corner.
You anoint my head with oil.

entries.theologicalSignificance: רֹאשׁ establishes order and priority. God is head over all. Human heads under God represent delegated authority. The crushed serpent's head anticipates Satan's defeat. The cornerstone becomes the head.
entries.ntConnection: Christ is head of the church (Eph 1:22, 5:23). He is head over every power (Col 2:10). The cornerstone prophecy fulfilled (Matt 21:42). Husbands are head as Christ is (Eph 5:23). Not a hair of your head will perish (Luke 21:18).

entries.title: Foot
entries.summary: רֶגֶל is the foot - the instrument of walking and symbol of pilgrimage. Feet carried worshipers to festivals. Removing sandals showed reverence. 'Under the feet' meant subjugation. Beautiful feet bring good news.
entries.ancientContext: Walking was the primary mode of travel. Foot-washing honored guests. Removing sandals acknowledged holy ground. Placing feet on enemies symbolized victory. 'Three times a year' (שָׁלֹשׁ רְגָלִים) meant three pilgrimage festivals.
entries.rootAnalysis: רֶגֶל occurs 247 times. The verb רָגַל means 'to go about, spy.' רְגָלִים can mean 'times' (festivals requiring foot travel). 'Footstool' (הֲדֹם רַגְלָיו) is where feet rest - applied to ark/temple.
entries.otUsage: רֶגֶל describes: (1) body part (Gen 8:9), (2) pilgrimage (Exod 23:14 - שָׁלֹשׁ רְגָלִים), (3) dominion ('under feet', Ps 8:7), (4) holy ground (Exod 3:5), (5) walking/conduct (Ps 119:105). Washing feet showed hospitality.

keyPassages.significance: Remove sandals from your feet - holy ground.
How beautiful on the mountains are feet of the messenger.
You put all things under his feet.

entries.theologicalSignificance: רֶגֶל connects journey and worship. Feet carry us to God. Removing sandals acknowledges holiness. Victory puts enemies under feet. The messenger's feet bring good news. 'Lamp to my feet' guides the path.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus washed disciples' feet (John 13). Beautiful feet bring the gospel (Rom 10:15). All things under Christ's feet (Eph 1:22). Woman anointed Jesus' feet (Luke 7:38). Shake dust from feet (Matt 10:14).

entries.title: Tongue/Language
entries.summary: לָשׁוֹן is the tongue - organ of speech and the language spoken. The tongue blesses and curses, speaks truth and lies. Death and life are in its power. Languages differentiate nations; Pentecost reversed Babel.
entries.ancientContext: The tongue was considered peculiarly powerful. 'Tongue of fire' was prophetic speech (Isa 5:24). Different tongues marked national identity. The wise controlled their tongue; fools let it loose.
entries.rootAnalysis: לָשׁוֹן occurs 117 times. It means: (1) anatomical tongue, (2) language (Gen 10:5), (3) speech/words (Ps 12:4), (4) tongue-shaped objects (Josh 7:21, 24 - 'wedge' of gold). The tongue shapes reality through speech.
entries.otUsage: לָשׁוֹן describes: (1) body part (Job 6:30), (2) language/speech (Gen 10:5, 20, 31), (3) slander ('evil tongue', Ps 140:12), (4) teaching (Isa 50:4), (5) confession (Isa 45:23). 'Bridling the tongue' is wisdom's mark.

keyPassages.significance: Death and life are in the power of the tongue.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֲדֹנָי יְהוִה נָתַן לִי לְשׁוֹן לִמּוּדִים
keyPassages.significance: The Lord YHWH gave me the tongue of disciples.
Keep your tongue from evil.

entries.theologicalSignificance: לָשׁוֹן teaches speech's power to create and destroy. The tongue reflects the heart. Wisdom controls the tongue; fools are controlled by it. God's word is spoken; our confession matters eternally.
entries.ntConnection: James devotes major section to tongue (Jas 3:1-12). Tongues of fire at Pentecost (Acts 2). Every tongue will confess (Phil 2:11). Speaking in tongues is spiritual gift (1 Cor 12-14). No guile in Jesus' mouth (1 Pet 2:22).

entries.title: Voice/Sound
entries.summary: קוֹל is voice or sound - audible communication carrying meaning. God's voice thunders from Sinai; His still small voice speaks to Elijah. Hearing the voice is obeying. Sound accompanies theophany.
entries.ancientContext: Sound was mysterious to ancients - invisible yet powerful. Thunder was divine voice. The ram's horn (שׁוֹפָר) sounded for war and worship. 'The voice of YHWH' was prophetic revelation. Creation responds to God's voice.
entries.rootAnalysis: קוֹל occurs 505 times. It encompasses: (1) human voice (Gen 27:22), (2) divine voice (Gen 3:8, 10), (3) sound/noise (Exod 20:18), (4) thunder (Ps 29), (5) cry/proclamation. 'Voice of YHWH' occurs ~40 times.
entries.otUsage: קוֹל describes: (1) speech (Gen 3:8 - 'voice of YHWH walking'), (2) thunder (Ps 29:3-9), (3) crying/shouting (Gen 21:16), (4) musical sound (Ps 98:5), (5) rumor/news (Gen 45:16). Obeying God's voice is covenant faithfulness.

keyPassages.significance: You heard the sound of words - voice without form.
A still small voice - God speaks quietly too.
The voice of YHWH over the waters - sevenfold repetition.

entries.theologicalSignificance: קוֹל shows God as speaking God. His voice creates, commands, and comforts. Hearing His voice means obedience. The voice at Sinai was fearsome; the still small voice was intimate. God's voice distinguishes Him from silent idols.
entries.ntConnection: Voice from heaven affirmed Jesus (Matt 3:17, 17:5). My sheep hear my voice (John 10:27). The dead will hear His voice (John 5:28). Voice of archangel at return (1 Thess 4:16). John heard a voice like many waters (Rev 1:15).

entries.title: Bone/Substance
entries.summary: עֶצֶם is bone - the structural framework of the body and symbol of essential identity. 'Bone of my bone' expresses closest kinship. Dry bones can live. Not a bone of Passover lamb was broken.
entries.ancientContext: Bones were last to decay, representing permanence. Joseph's bones were transported to Canaan. Touching bones caused impurity, yet Elisha's bones raised the dead. Bones 'rejoicing' meant deep inner joy.
entries.rootAnalysis: עֶצֶם occurs 126 times. Related verb עָצַם means 'to be strong.' Meanings include: (1) bone (Gen 2:23), (2) body (Gen 7:4 - 'that very day'), (3) substance (Prov 3:8), (4) self (Gen 29:14). עֲצָמוֹת (bones) represents the whole person.
entries.otUsage: עֶצֶם describes: (1) skeletal bones (Gen 2:23), (2) kinship ('my bone', Gen 29:14), (3) the same day (בְּעֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה, Gen 7:13), (4) inner person (Ps 35:10), (5) Passover lamb (Exod 12:46). Ezekiel's dry bones vision is climactic.

keyPassages.hebrew: זֹאת הַפַּעַם עֶצֶם מֵעֲצָמַי וּבָשָׂר מִבְּשָׂרִי
keyPassages.significance: Bone of my bone, flesh of my flesh - kinship.
Dry bones, hear YHWH's word - resurrection hope.
You shall not break a bone of it - Passover lamb.

entries.theologicalSignificance: עֶצֶם represents essential identity and potential resurrection. What seems permanent (bones) can live again. Kinship is 'bone deep.' The Passover lamb's unbroken bones foreshadowed Christ.
entries.ntConnection: Not a bone of Jesus was broken (John 19:36). Christ is bone of our bone (Eph 5:30). The valley of dry bones foreshadows resurrection. The body's members, though many, are one (1 Cor 12).

entries.title: Righteousness
entries.summary: צֶדֶק is righteousness - conformity to a standard, right relationship, and justice. It describes God's character, human ethics, and cosmic order. The righteous King will reign in righteousness.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient Near Eastern kings claimed to establish justice. Israel's צֶדֶק was grounded in YHWH's character, not mere social order. It meant living according to covenant relationship, vindicating the oppressed.
entries.rootAnalysis: צֶדֶק occurs 119 times. Feminine צְדָקָה (righteousness) 157 times. Adjective צַדִּיק (righteous) 206 times. Verb צָדַק (be righteous) 41 times. The root pervades ethical and legal vocabulary.
entries.otUsage: צֶדֶק describes: (1) God's nature (Deut 32:4), (2) just judgments (Ps 119:75), (3) ethical conduct (Gen 15:6), (4) legal vindication (Isa 50:8), (5) Messiah's reign (Isa 32:1). Often paired with מִשְׁפָּט (justice).

keyPassages.significance: Abraham believed YHWH - credited as righteousness.
Righteousness and justice are your throne's foundation.
A king will reign in righteousness.

entries.theologicalSignificance: צֶדֶק grounds ethics in God's nature rather than social convention. It includes both retributive and restorative aspects. The righteous God declares sinners righteous through faith - the gospel anticipated.
entries.ntConnection: Righteousness of God revealed in gospel (Rom 1:17). Christ is our righteousness (1 Cor 1:30). Abraham's faith righteousness grounds justification (Rom 4). Seek first God's kingdom and righteousness (Matt 6:33).

entries.title: Good
entries.summary: טוֹב is good - the fundamental positive value. God saw creation and declared it good. טוֹב describes moral goodness, aesthetic beauty, practical benefit, and emotional pleasure. 'Good' finds its standard in God.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient cultures had various concepts of good, often utilitarian or tied to gods' favor. Israel grounded טוֹב in creation - what God declares good is objectively good. The knowledge of good and evil was forbidden fruit.
entries.rootAnalysis: טוֹב occurs 559 times. Verb יָטַב (be good, well) 117 times. Abstract noun טוּב (goodness) 32 times. One of the most common words in Hebrew, spanning every domain of life and thought.
entries.otUsage: טוֹב describes: (1) creation (Gen 1:4), (2) moral rightness (Mic 6:8), (3) beauty (Gen 6:2), (4) prosperity (Deut 30:15), (5) kindness (1 Sam 25:15), (6) pleasure (Eccl 2:1). Often contrasted with רָע (evil).

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיַּרְא אֱלֹהִים אֶת־כָּל־אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂה וְהִנֵּה־טוֹב מְאֹד
keyPassages.significance: God saw all He made - behold, very good.
He has told you, O man, what is good.
Taste and see that YHWH is good.

entries.theologicalSignificance: טוֹב teaches that goodness is objective, rooted in God's nature and creative purpose. Creation is fundamentally good despite the fall. True goodness is doing justice, loving mercy, walking humbly (Mic 6:8).
entries.ntConnection: Why call me good? Only God is good (Mark 10:18). Good works prepared beforehand (Eph 2:10). Every good gift comes from Father of lights (James 1:17). Work together for good (Rom 8:28).

entries.title: Upright/Straight
entries.summary: יָשָׁר is straight or upright - describing both physical paths and moral character. The upright person walks without deviation from God's way. Israel was called 'Jeshurun' - the upright one.
entries.ancientContext: The metaphor of straight paths was universal - crooked paths meant danger and deception. Israel was to walk the straight path YHWH made. The Books of Jashar recorded the upright ones.
entries.rootAnalysis: יָשָׁר occurs 119 times as adjective. Noun יֹשֶׁר (uprightness) 14 times. Verb יָשַׁר (be straight) 27 times. מֵישָׁרִים (level places, equity) 19 times. יְשֻׁרוּן (Jeshurun) 4 times as Israel's poetic name.
entries.otUsage: יָשָׁר describes: (1) straight paths (Prov 2:13), (2) morally upright (Job 1:1), (3) right words (Job 6:25), (4) correct action (1 Kings 15:5), (5) Israel (Jeshurun, Deut 32:15). Often paired with צַדִּיק (righteous).

keyPassages.significance: A man blameless and upright, fearing God.
Those who leave paths of uprightness.
Make straight in the desert a highway.

entries.theologicalSignificance: יָשָׁר shows that ethics is about direction - walking straight on God's path. The upright are contrasted with the crooked. God's ways are יָשָׁר even when ours are not.
entries.ntConnection: Make straight the way of the Lord (John 1:23). Make straight paths for your feet (Heb 12:13). Crooked generation (Phil 2:15). Straight gate and narrow way (Matt 7:14).

entries.title: Truth/Faithfulness
entries.summary: אֱמֶת is truth - reliability, faithfulness, and correspondence to reality. It describes God's character, human speech, and genuine devotion. Truth is inseparable from faithfulness in Hebrew thought.
entries.ancientContext: Unlike Greek philosophical truth (abstract correspondence), Hebrew אֱמֶת was relational - a person of truth was dependable. Treaties required אֱמֶת. God's אֱמֶת meant He would keep His word.
entries.rootAnalysis: אֱמֶת occurs 127 times. From root אמן (be firm, faithful). Related to אָמֵן (amen, verily), אֱמוּנָה (faithfulness), and נֶאֱמָן (faithful). Truth and faithfulness are one concept.
entries.otUsage: אֱמֶת describes: (1) God's nature (Ps 31:5), (2) reliable speech (Prov 12:19), (3) genuine worship (Josh 24:14), (4) covenant keeping (Gen 24:49), (5) just judgment (Zech 7:9). Often paired with חֶסֶד (steadfast love).

keyPassages.significance: God of truth - into Your hands I commit my spirit.
Abounding in steadfast love and truth.
The sum of Your word is truth.

entries.theologicalSignificance: אֱמֶת unites intellectual and moral truth. God's word is true because He is faithful. Serving in אֱמֶת means wholehearted, genuine devotion, not mere ritual. Truth-telling reflects God's character.
entries.ntConnection: Jesus is the way, truth, and life (John 14:6). Spirit of truth guides into all truth (John 16:13). Worship in spirit and truth (John 4:24). Truth will set you free (John 8:32).

entries.title: Mercy/Compassion
entries.summary: רַחֲמִים is deep mercy - visceral compassion from the womb. The plural form intensifies the emotion. God's mercies are new every morning. He is Father of mercies.
entries.ancientContext: The connection to רֶחֶם (womb) expressed the deepest human bond. A mother's love for her nursing child epitomized mercy. Kings were supposed to show רַחֲמִים to the conquered.
entries.rootAnalysis: רַחֲמִים occurs 40 times (always plural). From רֶחֶם (womb). Verb רָחַם (have compassion) 47 times. Adjective רַחוּם (compassionate) 13 times. The womb-origin gives mercy its visceral quality.
entries.otUsage: רַחֲמִים describes: (1) God's nature (Ps 145:9), (2) maternal love (1 Kings 3:26), (3) brotherly feeling (Gen 43:30), (4) covenant mercy (Deut 13:17), (5) royal clemency (1 Kings 8:50). Core to YHWH's self-revelation.

keyPassages.significance: His mercies never end; new every morning.
As a father has compassion on children, YHWH has compassion.
Can a woman forget her nursing child? - Even more, I won't forget.

entries.theologicalSignificance: רַחֲמִים reveals God's parental heart. His mercy is not cold clemency but warm compassion. The womb-connection shows mercy as life-giving and nurturing. His mercies renew daily.
entries.ntConnection: Father of mercies and God of all comfort (2 Cor 1:3). Be merciful as your Father is merciful (Luke 6:36). Rich in mercy (Eph 2:4). Tender mercies of our God (Luke 1:78).

entries.title: Humble/Meek
entries.summary: עָנָו is the humble or meek one - lowly in circumstances or spirit, dependent on God. Moses was most humble. The meek will inherit the earth. Humility before YHWH is prerequisite for exaltation.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient societies valued honor and status. Israel's countercultural ethic valued the עָנָו - those who didn't assert themselves but trusted God. The poor were often עֲנָוִים, oppressed yet faithful.
entries.rootAnalysis: עָנָו occurs 21 times. Related עָנִי (afflicted, poor) 80 times. From root ענה (be bowed down, afflicted). עֲנָוָה (humility) 5 times. The concepts of poverty and humility merge.
entries.otUsage: עָנָו describes: (1) Moses (Num 12:3), (2) messianic king (Zech 9:9), (3) the faithful poor (Ps 37:11), (4) those God exalts (Prov 3:34), (5) those who receive salvation (Ps 149:4). God opposes the proud.

keyPassages.significance: Moses was very humble - more than any person.
Your king comes humble, riding on a donkey.
The meek shall inherit the earth.

entries.theologicalSignificance: עָנָו teaches that power is not self-assertion but God-dependence. The humble receive what the proud grasp for. God dwells with the lowly. Moses' meekness made him usable.
entries.ntConnection: Blessed are the meek (Matt 5:5). Jesus meek and lowly (Matt 11:29). King comes humble on donkey (Matt 21:5). God gives grace to the humble (James 4:6, 1 Pet 5:5).

entries.title: Blameless/Complete
entries.summary: תָּמִים is blameless or complete - whole, without defect. Sacrificial animals had to be תָּמִים. Abraham was told to walk before God and be blameless. It describes integrity of heart and life.
entries.ancientContext: Animals for sacrifice couldn't have defects. Similarly, priests and worshipers should be whole-hearted. תָּמִים didn't mean sinless perfection but undivided loyalty and moral integrity.
entries.rootAnalysis: תָּמִים occurs 91 times. From root תָּמַם (be complete). Related to תֹּם (integrity) 23 times, תָּם (complete, perfect) 14 times. The root emphasizes wholeness rather than flawlessness.
entries.otUsage: תָּמִים describes: (1) sacrificial animals (Lev 1:3), (2) moral integrity (Gen 17:1), (3) God's way (Ps 18:30), (4) His law (Ps 19:7), (5) covenant faithfulness (Deut 18:13). Walk תָּמִים means undivided devotion.

keyPassages.significance: Walk before Me and be blameless.
The law of YHWH is perfect.
You shall be blameless before YHWH your God.

entries.theologicalSignificance: תָּמִים reveals that God desires wholeness - undivided hearts. The perfect sacrifice foreshadows Christ. Walking תָּמִים is possible through grace, not perfection but direction.
entries.ntConnection: Present yourselves perfect in Christ (Col 1:28). Perfect as your Father is perfect (Matt 5:48). Christ offered Himself without blemish (Heb 9:14). Lamb without blemish (1 Pet 1:19).

entries.title: Faithful/Trustworthy
entries.summary: נֶאֱמָן is faithful or trustworthy - one who can be relied upon. God is the faithful God who keeps covenant. Faithful servants and witnesses are נֶאֱמָן. The word shares its root with אָמֵן (amen).
entries.ancientContext: Faithfulness was essential for social trust - servants, messengers, witnesses needed to be נֶאֱמָן. More importantly, God's faithfulness was the foundation of Israel's existence. He keeps His word.
entries.rootAnalysis: נֶאֱמָן is the Niphal participle of אָמַן (be firm). Occurs 45 times. Related to אֱמוּנָה (faithfulness), אֱמֶת (truth), and אָמֵן (amen). The root family expresses reliability and trustworthiness.
entries.otUsage: נֶאֱמָן describes: (1) God (Deut 7:9), (2) Moses (Num 12:7), (3) priests (1 Sam 2:35), (4) witnesses (Isa 8:2), (5) messengers (Prov 25:13). Davidic house would be נֶאֱמָן (2 Sam 7:16).

keyPassages.significance: The faithful God who keeps covenant and steadfast love.

keyPassages.hebrew: לֹא־כֵן עַבְדִּי מֹשֶׁה בְּכָל־בֵּיתִי נֶאֱמָן הוּא
keyPassages.significance: Moses My servant, faithful in all My house.
I will raise up a faithful priest.

entries.theologicalSignificance: נֶאֱמָן teaches that faithfulness is God's fundamental character and should mark His people. A faithful witness speaks truth. A faithful servant is reliable. We say 'amen' because God is נֶאֱמָן.
entries.ntConnection: Faithful and true witness (Rev 3:14). God is faithful (1 Cor 1:9, 10:13). Jesus faithful high priest (Heb 2:17). Be faithful unto death (Rev 2:10). Well done, faithful servant (Matt 25:21).

entries.title: Godly/Loyal One
entries.summary: חָסִיד is the godly or loyal one - one who practices חֶסֶד (steadfast love). The חֲסִידִים are the faithful community who maintain covenant loyalty. Psalms frequently invoke them.
entries.ancientContext: The חֲסִידִים were the faithful remnant who maintained loyalty to YHWH and His covenant. Later Judaism developed the Hasidim movement, and Christianity the concept of 'saints.'
entries.rootAnalysis: חָסִיד occurs 32 times. From חֶסֶד (steadfast love). The חָסִיד practices and receives חֶסֶד. Plural חֲסִידִים describes the community of the faithful.
entries.otUsage: חָסִיד describes: (1) faithful Israelites (Ps 149:1), (2) those loved by God (Ps 4:3), (3) those protected (Ps 97:10), (4) Samuel (1 Sam 2:9), (5) God Himself (Ps 145:17, remarkably). The godly are covenant-keepers.

keyPassages.significance: His praise in the assembly of the godly.
Know that YHWH has set apart the godly for Himself.
And godly/loyal in all His works - said of God.

entries.theologicalSignificance: חָסִיד shows that covenant faithfulness creates a community. The godly are those who both receive and practice steadfast love. Remarkably, God Himself is called חָסִיד - the ultimate loyal one.
entries.ntConnection: The saints (ἅγιοι) parallel חֲסִידִים. Let your holy one not see decay (Acts 2:27, Ps 16:10). Saints preserved in God's love (Jude 1). Communion of saints. Holy and beloved (Col 3:12).

entries.title: Righteous One
entries.summary: צַדִּיק is the righteous one - person who lives in right relationship with God and others. Abraham was credited צְדָקָה for believing. The righteous shall live by faith. Noah was צַדִּיק.
entries.ancientContext: Being צַדִּיק meant meeting the standard of covenant relationship. It was forensic (declared right) and ethical (doing right). The contrast רָשָׁע (wicked) defined moral categories.
entries.rootAnalysis: צַדִּיק occurs 206 times - one of the most frequent ethical terms. The root צדק family dominates OT ethics. צַדִּיק is often contrasted with רָשָׁע (wicked) in Proverbs and Psalms.
entries.otUsage: צַדִּיק describes: (1) Noah (Gen 6:9), (2) Abraham's descendants (Gen 18:23-28), (3) just judges (Deut 16:19), (4) the ideal person (Ps 1), (5) Messiah (Isa 53:11). The righteous flourish like palm trees.

keyPassages.significance: Noah was a righteous man, blameless.
The righteous shall live by his faith.
My righteous Servant will make many righteous.

entries.theologicalSignificance: צַדִּיק integrates status and behavior. One is declared צַדִּיק by faith (Gen 15:6) and lives as צַדִּיק in conduct. The צַדִּיק/רָשָׁע contrast runs through Scripture. Messiah makes many צַדִּיק.
entries.ntConnection: The Just One (Acts 3:14, 7:52). Righteous by faith (Rom 1:17, Gal 3:11, Heb 10:38). No one righteous (Rom 3:10). Christ made sin so we become righteousness (2 Cor 5:21).

entries.title: Innocent/Clean
entries.summary: נָקִי is innocent or clean - free from guilt or wrongdoing. Shedding innocent blood was a grave sin. The נָקִי have clean hands and pure hearts. God acquits the innocent.
entries.ancientContext: Legal innocence mattered for justice. Shedding נָקִי blood polluted the land. Judges had to protect the innocent from false accusation. Being נָקִי meant having no guilt against you.
entries.rootAnalysis: נָקִי occurs 43 times. Verb נָקָה (be clean, innocent) 44 times. Related to נִקָּיוֹן (innocence). The legal-cultic concept of being free from guilt or contamination.
entries.otUsage: נָקִי describes: (1) innocent blood (Deut 19:10), (2) guiltless persons (1 Sam 19:5), (3) clean hands (Job 17:9), (4) those God protects (Ps 10:8), (5) acquittal language (Exod 20:7). Not taking God's name in vain.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְלֹא יִשָּׁפֵךְ דָּם נָקִי בְּקֶרֶב אַרְצְךָ
keyPassages.significance: Innocent blood must not be shed in your land.

keyPassages.hebrew: לֹא יְנַקֶּה יְהוָה אֵת אֲשֶׁר־יִשָּׂא אֶת־שְׁמוֹ לַשָּׁוְא
keyPassages.significance: YHWH will not hold guiltless one who misuses His name.
Clean hands and pure heart - who may stand.

entries.theologicalSignificance: נָקִי shows that God is a just judge who protects the innocent and punishes the guilty. Innocent blood defiles land and cries for justice. Clean hands require clean hearts.
entries.ntConnection: I am innocent of this man's blood (Matt 27:24 - ironic). Judas betrayed innocent blood (Matt 27:4). Hearts sprinkled clean from evil conscience (Heb 10:22). If we confess, He cleanses (1 John 1:9).

entries.title: Pure/Clean
entries.summary: בַּר is pure or clean - describing moral purity and clarity. A pure heart, pure lips. Related to grain that has been winnowed clean. The pure in heart will see God.
entries.ancientContext: Purity came from winnowing - separating grain from chaff. Moral purity meant being sifted, tested, refined. בַּר described what had been purified of impurity, especially in the heart.
entries.rootAnalysis: בַּר (pure) occurs 7 times. Related to בָּרַר (purify, select) 15 times, and בֹּר (cleanness) 5 times. The winnowing/purifying imagery underlies the ethical meaning.
entries.otUsage: בַּר describes: (1) pure heart (Ps 24:4), (2) pure hands (Ps 73:1), (3) pure prayers (Job 11:4), (4) moral cleanness (Ps 19:8). Often paired with other purity terms like זַךְ and נָקִי.

keyPassages.significance: Clean of hands and pure of heart.

keyPassages.hebrew: אַךְ טוֹב לְיִשְׂרָאֵל אֱלֹהִים לְבָרֵי לֵבָב
keyPassages.significance: Surely God is good to Israel, to the pure in heart.
One who loves purity of heart.

entries.theologicalSignificance: בַּר shows that God values inner purity. The heart must be winnowed of wrong motives. Purity of heart brings divine encounter. Moral purity is possible through divine cleansing.
entries.ntConnection: Blessed are the pure in heart, they shall see God (Matt 5:8). Create in me a clean heart (Ps 51:10 fulfilled). Pure in heart love sincerely (1 Tim 1:5). Keep yourself pure (1 Tim 5:22).

entries.title: Pure/Clear
entries.summary: זַךְ is pure or clear - describing transparency and cleanness. Used for pure oil and pure hearts. The concept emphasizes clarity without mixture or contamination.
entries.ancientContext: Cultic purity required unmixed substances - pure olive oil, pure incense. זַךְ extended to moral clarity: unmixed motives, transparent intentions. Pure devotion without hypocrisy.
entries.rootAnalysis: זַךְ occurs 11 times. Verb זָכַךְ (be pure, clean) 4 times. Related to זֹכֶר (cleanness). The root emphasizes clarity and freedom from contamination.
entries.otUsage: זַךְ describes: (1) pure olive oil (Exod 27:20), (2) pure incense (Exod 30:34), (3) clean/innocent (Job 8:6), (4) pure prayer (Job 16:17), (5) moral cleanness (Prov 20:11). Cultic and ethical overlap.

keyPassages.significance: Pure olive oil for the lampstand.
If you are pure and upright.

keyPassages.hebrew: גַּם בְּמַעֲלָלָיו יִתְנַכֶּר־נָעַר אִם־זַךְ וְאִם־יָשָׁר פָּעֳלוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Even a child is known by deeds - pure and upright.

entries.theologicalSignificance: זַךְ connects cultic purity with moral integrity. As oil for the sanctuary had to be pure, so must the heart. God sees through to purity of motive, not just external action.
entries.ntConnection: Pure religion (James 1:27). Pure and undefiled (James 3:17). Pure heart (1 Tim 1:5). Whatever is pure (Phil 4:8). Present you as pure virgin (2 Cor 11:2).

entries.title: Established/Right
entries.summary: נָכוֹן is established or right - what is fixed, reliable, and correct. The heart can be established before God. His throne is established. The word connotes both stability and correctness.
entries.ancientContext: Establishing something meant making it firm and permanent. A נָכוֹן heart was steadfast in devotion. A נָכוֹן word was reliable truth. The opposite was wavering or false.
entries.rootAnalysis: נָכוֹן is Niphal participle of כּוּן (be established). Root occurs 219 times across forms. הֵכִין (establish, prepare) is Hiphil. מָכוֹן (place, foundation). The root pervades stability language.
entries.otUsage: נָכוֹן describes: (1) God's throne (Ps 93:2), (2) faithful hearts (Ps 57:7), (3) reliable words (Prov 12:19), (4) correct judgments (Job 42:7), (5) prepared things (1 Chr 29:18). Stability and rectitude unite.

keyPassages.significance: Your throne is established from of old.
My heart is steadfast, O God, my heart is steadfast.
You and your kingdom will not be established.

entries.theologicalSignificance: נָכוֹן unites stability with righteousness. What God establishes endures. A heart נָכוֹן toward God is fixed in loyalty. Truth stands because it's established on reality.
entries.ntConnection: Built on rock, house stands (Matt 7:25). Establish your hearts (James 5:8). Established in the faith (Col 2:7). Kingdom that cannot be shaken (Heb 12:28). Hearts established by grace (Heb 13:9).

entries.title: Day (Day of YHWH)
entries.summary: יוֹם is day, but eschatologically refers to the Day of YHWH - the climactic moment of divine intervention. That Day brings judgment and salvation, darkness for enemies and light for the faithful.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient peoples marked time by days. But יוֹם יְהוָה became a technical term for final judgment. Early prophets warned that Israel misunderstood it - expecting blessing, they would face judgment.
entries.rootAnalysis: יוֹם occurs 2,304 times - one of Hebrew's most common words. יוֹם יְהוָה (Day of YHWH) appears 16 times explicitly, plus many allusions. הַיּוֹם הַהוּא (that day) becomes eschatological formula.
entries.otUsage: יוֹם describes: (1) ordinary day (Gen 1:5), (2) Day of YHWH (Joel 2:1), (3) eschatological 'that day' (Isa 2:11), (4) day of judgment (Amos 5:18), (5) day of salvation (Isa 49:8). Context determines meaning.

keyPassages.hebrew: הוֹי הַמִּתְאַוִּים אֶת־יוֹם יְהוָה... חֹשֶׁךְ הוּא וְלֹא־אוֹר
keyPassages.significance: Woe to you who desire the Day of YHWH - darkness not light.

keyPassages.hebrew: לִפְנֵי בּוֹא יוֹם יְהוָה הַגָּדוֹל וְהַנּוֹרָא
keyPassages.significance: Before the great and terrible Day of YHWH comes.

keyPassages.hebrew: לִפְנֵי בּוֹא יוֹם יְהוָה הַגָּדוֹל וְהַנּוֹרָא
keyPassages.significance: Before the great and dreadful Day of YHWH.

entries.theologicalSignificance: יוֹם יְהוָה teaches that history has a goal. God will act decisively. For covenant breakers, judgment; for the faithful, vindication. The Day is both terrible and wonderful.
entries.ntConnection: Day of the Lord comes like thief (1 Thess 5:2, 2 Pet 3:10). Day of judgment (Matt 12:36). That Day (Matt 7:22, 2 Tim 1:12). Day of Christ (Phil 1:6, 10). Great day of their wrath (Rev 6:17).

entries.title: End/Latter Days
entries.summary: אַחֲרִית is the end or latter part - often 'the latter days' (בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים). It looks forward to the eschatological future when God's purposes come to fulfillment.
entries.ancientContext: Israel's future hope wasn't cyclical but linear - moving toward אַחֲרִית. The patriarchal blessings and prophetic oracles looked to what would happen בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים.
entries.rootAnalysis: אַחֲרִית occurs 61 times. From אַחַר (after, behind). Denotes what comes after, the outcome, the future. בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים (in the latter days) is eschatological formula (Gen 49:1, Isa 2:2).
entries.otUsage: אַחֲרִית describes: (1) latter days (Gen 49:1), (2) end of matter (Deut 11:12), (3) future hope (Jer 29:11), (4) outcome/reward (Prov 23:18), (5) messianic age (Isa 2:2). Hope shapes present action.

keyPassages.significance: What will happen in the latter days - Jacob's prophetic blessing.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהָיָה בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים נָכוֹן יִהְיֶה הַר בֵּית־יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: In the latter days, the mountain of YHWH's house established.
To give you a future and a hope.

entries.theologicalSignificance: אַחֲרִית grounds hope in God's plan. The end is not random but purposed. What God begins, He completes. The latter days bring messianic fulfillment. Present suffering has future resolution.
entries.ntConnection: Last days inaugurated at Pentecost (Acts 2:17). In these last days God spoke by Son (Heb 1:2). Scoffers in last days (2 Pet 3:3). Last days difficult times (2 Tim 3:1).

entries.title: Eternity/Forever
entries.summary: עוֹלָם is eternity - time without visible limit, whether past or future. It describes God's nature, His covenant, and His kingdom. From everlasting to everlasting, He is God.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient peoples struggled with concepts of infinity. עוֹלָם meant 'hidden time' - time beyond human horizon. Applied to God, it meant He transcends temporal limits. Applied to covenant, it meant permanent validity.
entries.rootAnalysis: עוֹלָם occurs 439 times. From עלם (hidden). Means time hidden from view - whether ancient past or distant future. לְעוֹלָם (forever), מֵעוֹלָם (from eternity), עַד־עוֹלָם (to eternity).
entries.otUsage: עוֹלָם describes: (1) God's existence (Ps 90:2), (2) covenant permanence (Gen 17:7), (3) everlasting kingdom (Dan 2:44), (4) ancient times (Isa 63:9), (5) perpetual ordinances (Exod 12:14). Context determines past or future.

keyPassages.significance: From everlasting to everlasting, You are God.

keyPassages.hebrew: יְקִים אֱלָהּ שְׁמַיָּא מַלְכוּ דִּי לְעָלְמִין לָא תִתְחַבַּל
keyPassages.significance: God of heaven will set up an eternal kingdom.
YHWH is the eternal God.

entries.theologicalSignificance: עוֹלָם teaches that God transcends time. His promises are permanent. His kingdom has no end. We live in time, but He inhabits eternity. This grounds unshakeable hope.
entries.ntConnection: Eternal life (ζωὴ αἰώνιος) parallels עוֹלָם. Before the world began (2 Tim 1:9). King eternal (1 Tim 1:17). Eternal kingdom (2 Pet 1:11). From ages past (Rom 16:25).

entries.title: End/Limit
entries.summary: קֵץ is the end - the termination point, the limit. In Daniel's apocalyptic visions, the קֵץ is the end of history as we know it. Every temporary thing has its קֵץ; God's kingdom has none.
entries.ancientContext: Apocalyptic literature calculated the קֵץ - when would God intervene? Daniel's sealed visions concerned the 'time of the end.' The קֵץ meant both judgment on oppressors and vindication of the faithful.
entries.rootAnalysis: קֵץ occurs 67 times. From קצץ (cut off). The cutting-off point, the terminus. In apocalyptic contexts (Daniel), it becomes technical: עֵת קֵץ (time of the end), קֵץ הַיָּמִים (end of days).
entries.otUsage: קֵץ describes: (1) limit/boundary (Job 28:3), (2) end of period (Gen 8:6), (3) end of flesh (Gen 6:13), (4) apocalyptic end (Dan 8:17), (5) termination (Ezek 7:2-6). Often with time words.

keyPassages.significance: The vision concerns the time of the end.
The end has come! The end has come!
Seal the book until the time of the end.

entries.theologicalSignificance: קֵץ teaches that evil is time-limited. Oppression has an end. God will bring history to its appointed terminus. The קֵץ is both terrifying (judgment) and liberating (deliverance).
entries.ntConnection: End of the ages has come (1 Cor 10:11). End of all things is at hand (1 Pet 4:7). Until the end of the age (Matt 28:20). Then comes the end (1 Cor 15:24).

entries.title: New
entries.summary: חָדָשׁ is new - fresh, unprecedented, renewed. God does new things: new covenant, new heart, new heavens and earth. The eschatological hope is for radical newness, not mere improvement.
entries.ancientContext: Ancient societies valued tradition over innovation. But Israel's God announced חָדָשׁ things - what hadn't existed before. The new covenant, new creation, new song - eschatological newness transcends repetition.
entries.rootAnalysis: חָדָשׁ occurs 53 times. Verb חָדַשׁ (renew) 10 times. Related to חֹדֶשׁ (new moon, month). The root carries freshness, renewal, what has not been before.
entries.otUsage: חָדָשׁ describes: (1) new things God does (Isa 42:9), (2) new covenant (Jer 31:31), (3) new heart (Ezek 36:26), (4) new heavens/earth (Isa 65:17), (5) new song (Ps 96:1). Eschatological renewal.

keyPassages.significance: Behold, I am doing a new thing; now it springs forth.

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנֵּה יָמִים בָּאִים... וְכָרַתִּי... בְּרִית חֲדָשָׁה
keyPassages.significance: Days are coming when I will make a new covenant.

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנְנִי בוֹרֵא שָׁמַיִם חֲדָשִׁים וָאָרֶץ חֲדָשָׁה
keyPassages.significance: Behold, I create new heavens and a new earth.

entries.theologicalSignificance: חָדָשׁ teaches that God is not finished. He makes all things new. The future isn't repetition but transformation. New covenant surpasses old. New creation transcends present order.
entries.ntConnection: New covenant in My blood (Luke 22:20). New creation in Christ (2 Cor 5:17). New commandment (John 13:34). New heaven and new earth (Rev 21:1). Behold, I make all things new (Rev 21:5).

entries.title: Hope/Expectation
entries.summary: תִּקְוָה is hope - confident expectation of future good. Israel's hope was in YHWH, not circumstances. The cord of תִּקְוָה that saved Rahab became symbol of salvation hope.
entries.ancientContext: The root קוה means 'wait with tension' like a stretched cord. תִּקְוָה is the thing hoped for, the expectation. For Israel, תִּקְוָה centered on God's promises, not human possibilities.
entries.rootAnalysis: תִּקְוָה occurs 34 times. From קָוָה (wait, hope). Related to קַו (line, cord). תִּקְוָה is the object hoped for or the act of hoping. Both present attitude and future reality.
entries.otUsage: תִּקְוָה describes: (1) Israel's hope (Jer 29:11), (2) hope in God (Ps 71:5), (3) Rahab's cord (Josh 2:18), (4) end/future (Prov 23:18), (5) resurrection hope (Job 14:7). The righteous have תִּקְוָה.

keyPassages.significance: To give you a future and a hope.

keyPassages.hebrew: בָּרוּךְ הַגֶּבֶר אֲשֶׁר יִבְטַח בַּיהוָה וְהָיָה יְהוָה מִבְטַחוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Blessed is the man who trusts in YHWH, whose hope is YHWH.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי אִם־יֵשׁ אַחֲרִית וְתִקְוָתְךָ לֹא תִכָּרֵת
keyPassages.significance: Surely there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

entries.theologicalSignificance: תִּקְוָה teaches that biblical hope is certain expectation, not wishful thinking. It's grounded in God's character and promises. The righteous have תִּקְוָה; the wicked do not.
entries.ntConnection: Hope that does not disappoint (Rom 5:5). Christ in you, hope of glory (Col 1:27). Living hope through resurrection (1 Pet 1:3). Hope as anchor (Heb 6:19). God of hope (Rom 15:13).

entries.title: Arise/Rise Up
entries.summary: קוּם is to arise or stand up - used for resurrection from death. The dead will arise. Daniel's sleepers will awake. קוּם connects to eschatological resurrection hope.
entries.ancientContext: Rising from lying down was natural metaphor for revival from death. While OT resurrection hope is often implicit, passages like Isaiah 26 and Daniel 12 use קוּם for eschatological rising.
entries.rootAnalysis: קוּם occurs 628 times - extremely common. Basic meaning: rise, stand up. Extended: establish, confirm, arise (for action). In resurrection contexts: rise from death (Isa 26:19, Job 19:25).
entries.otUsage: קוּם describes: (1) physical rising (Gen 19:1), (2) arising for action (Judg 5:12), (3) resurrection (Isa 26:19), (4) establishing (Gen 6:18), (5) rising against enemies (Deut 28:7). Context determines nuance.

keyPassages.significance: Your dead shall live; their bodies shall rise.
Many who sleep in dust will awake.
My Redeemer lives and will stand upon the earth.

entries.theologicalSignificance: קוּם grounded Israel's resurrection hope. Death is not final; God raises the dead. The body will rise. Ezekiel's dry bones vision uses this language. Resurrection is bodily, not just spiritual.
entries.ntConnection: He is not here; He is risen (Matt 28:6 - ἠγέρθη). Raised on third day (1 Cor 15:4). Dead in Christ rise first (1 Thess 4:16). Resurrection and the life (John 11:25).

entries.title: Return/Restore
entries.summary: שׁוּב is to return or restore - fundamental to repentance and eschatological restoration. Israel returns to God and to the land. שׁוּב שְׁבוּת means restoration of fortunes.
entries.ancientContext: Exile meant being away from home and God. שׁוּב described both physical return to land and spiritual return to YHWH. The prophets called for שׁוּב and promised שׁוּב שְׁבוּת.
entries.rootAnalysis: שׁוּב occurs 1,066 times - one of Hebrew's most frequent verbs. Meanings: return physically, turn back, repent, restore. שׁוּב שְׁבוּת (restore fortunes) is eschatological formula (Jer 30:3, Ezek 39:25).
entries.otUsage: שׁוּב describes: (1) physical return (Gen 3:19), (2) repentance (Jer 3:12), (3) God turning (Ps 90:13), (4) restoration (Jer 30:3), (5) apostasy (turn away, Jer 8:4). Direction determines meaning.

keyPassages.significance: I will restore the fortunes of My people Israel and Judah.
Return, O Israel, to YHWH your God.
He will turn the hearts of fathers to children.

entries.theologicalSignificance: שׁוּב teaches that relationship can be restored. Exile is not permanent. God welcomes return. The great restoration involves both repentance and divine initiative. Eschatological return fulfills exile's reversal.
entries.ntConnection: Repent for kingdom is near (Matt 4:17). Return to Shepherd (1 Pet 2:25). Restoration of all things (Acts 3:21). Prodigal returns (Luke 15). I will come again (John 14:3).

entries.title: Come/Enter
entries.summary: בּוֹא is to come or enter - used for God's coming, Messiah's coming, and the coming Day. 'Days are coming' (יָמִים בָּאִים) introduces eschatological promises. The one who comes is blessed.
entries.ancientContext: Coming implied movement toward a goal. Eschatologically, God comes to judge and save. The Coming One (הַבָּא) became messianic title. Entering the land, the temple, God's rest - all use בּוֹא.
entries.rootAnalysis: בּוֹא occurs 2,592 times - the most common Hebrew verb. Basic: come, enter, arrive. הַבָּא (the one coming) is participial. הֵבִיא (Hiphil: bring). Eschatological formulas: יָמִים בָּאִים, הִנֵּה יוֹם בָּא.
entries.otUsage: בּוֹא describes: (1) physical coming (Gen 6:18), (2) Messiah coming (Zech 9:9), (3) days coming (Jer 31:31), (4) entering land/rest (Deut 12:9), (5) God coming (Isa 40:10). Direction and agent vary.

keyPassages.significance: Behold, your king comes to you.
The Lord whom you seek will suddenly come to His temple.
Blessed is he who comes in the name of YHWH.

entries.theologicalSignificance: בּוֹא shows eschatology as arrival - God comes, Messiah comes, the Day comes. The future moves toward us. We await the Coming One. Entering God's rest is the goal.
entries.ntConnection: He who comes in name of Lord (Matt 21:9). The Coming One (Matt 11:3). I will come again (John 14:3). Come, Lord Jesus (Rev 22:20). When He comes (1 John 2:28).

entries.title: Forever/Perpetuity
entries.summary: נֶצַח is perpetuity or forever - enduring duration. Often in phrases לָנֶצַח (forever) expressing God's permanent character or permanent states. God's anger is not forever; His love is.
entries.ancientContext: נֶצַח expressed what endures without end. Used with both positive (God's faithfulness) and negative (permanent destruction). The Psalms frequently ask whether God will reject forever or restore.
entries.rootAnalysis: נֶצַח occurs 43 times. Related to נָצַח (supervise, excel, endure). The root conveys eminence and permanence. Often in לָנֶצַח (to perpetuity) or נֶצַח נְצָחִים (forever and ever).
entries.otUsage: נֶצַח describes: (1) forever (Ps 9:18), (2) perpetual (Isa 34:10), (3) enduring (Ps 16:11), (4) permanent anger (Jer 3:5), (5) always/continually (Amos 1:11). Context determines temporal scope.

keyPassages.significance: At Your right hand pleasures forevermore.
He will not always accuse, nor forever be angry.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי לֹא לְעוֹלָם אָרִיב וְלֹא לָנֶצַח אֶקְצוֹף
keyPassages.significance: I will not contend forever or be always angry.

entries.theologicalSignificance: נֶצַח shows that God's character determines what's permanent. His anger passes; His love endures. The righteous have eternal pleasures. Permanent destruction awaits the wicked.
entries.ntConnection: Eternal life (John 3:16). Eternal glory (2 Cor 4:17). Eternal comfort (2 Thess 2:16). We shall always be with the Lord (1 Thess 4:17). I am with you always (Matt 28:20).

entries.title: Perpetuity/Eternity
entries.summary: עַד is perpetuity or eternity - duration without end. In עֲדֵי עַד (forever and ever) and לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד it intensifies eternal meaning. God's throne is forever and ever.
entries.ancientContext: עַד expressed the outer limit of time. Combined with עוֹלָם in liturgical formulas for emphasis. Royal and divine forever-ness was claimed using עַד. The eternal God inhabits עַד.
entries.rootAnalysis: עַד occurs 49 times as noun meaning perpetuity. From root עוד (advance, continue). Common in combinations: לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד, עֲדֵי עַד, מֵעַתָּה וְעַד־עוֹלָם. Strengthens eternal expressions.
entries.otUsage: עַד describes: (1) forever and ever (Ps 45:6), (2) eternal God (Isa 57:15), (3) perpetual duration (Ps 21:4), (4) continuous existence (Mic 4:5), (5) everlasting praise (Ps 145:1-2). Liturgical frequency.

keyPassages.significance: Your throne, O God, is forever and ever.
Who dwells in eternity, whose name is Holy.
I will bless Your name forever and ever.

entries.theologicalSignificance: עַד expresses ultimate permanence. God inhabits eternity. His throne endures forever and ever. Doxologies use עַד to stretch praise beyond temporal limits.
entries.ntConnection: Forever and ever (εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων) in doxologies. To Him be glory forever (Rom 16:27). King eternal (1 Tim 1:17). The kingdom of our Lord forever (Rev 11:15).

entries.title: Continually/Always
entries.summary: תָּמִיד is continually or always - unbroken duration without interruption. The תָּמִיד offering was daily perpetual sacrifice. God's presence was תָּמִיד before His people.
entries.ancientContext: The תָּמִיד was the daily burnt offering (morning and evening) that never ceased. It represented Israel's continuous devotion. Daniel's תָּמִיד being taken away was ultimate desecration.
entries.rootAnalysis: תָּמִיד occurs 104 times. From root meaning 'stretch.' Adverb meaning continuously, perpetually. הַתָּמִיד (the תָּמִיד) refers specifically to daily sacrifice. Cultic and general uses.
entries.otUsage: תָּמִיד describes: (1) daily offering (Exod 29:42), (2) continual bread (Exod 25:30), (3) eternal lamp (Exod 27:20), (4) continuous praise (Ps 34:1), (5) constant presence (Ps 16:8). Unbroken continuity.

keyPassages.significance: A continual burnt offering throughout your generations.
I have set YHWH always before me.
From the time the daily sacrifice is taken away.

entries.theologicalSignificance: תָּמִיד shows that covenant relationship is continuous, not episodic. Worship should be perpetual. God's presence is constant. The removal of תָּמִיד signals ultimate crisis.
entries.ntConnection: Pray without ceasing (1 Thess 5:17). Continual sacrifice of praise (Heb 13:15). Always in prayer (Acts 2:42). Abide in Me (John 15:4). Lo, I am with you always (Matt 28:20).

entries.title: Generation/Age
entries.summary: דּוֹר is generation or age - a period marked by those living together. God's faithfulness extends לְדֹר וָדֹר (from generation to generation). Past and future generations form continuous covenant community.
entries.ancientContext: Generations marked time in genealogical cultures. Each דּוֹר received and transmitted tradition. God's covenant spanned דֹּרוֹת (generations). Telling children ensured continuity לְדֹר דֹּר.
entries.rootAnalysis: דּוֹר occurs 167 times. Meanings: (1) generation as people (evil generation), (2) generation as time period (40 years), (3) age/era. לְדֹר וָדֹר, דֹּר לְדֹר (generation to generation) express continuity.
entries.otUsage: דּוֹר describes: (1) people of an era (Deut 32:5), (2) time period (Gen 15:16), (3) posterity (Ps 102:18), (4) age/era (Eccl 1:4), (5) dwelling (Isa 38:12). Generational thinking pervades Torah.

keyPassages.significance: His faithfulness to all generations.

keyPassages.hebrew: זֶה־שְּׁמִי לְעֹלָם וְזֶה זִכְרִי לְדֹר דֹּר
keyPassages.significance: This is My name forever, My memorial to all generations.
One generation shall praise Your works to another.

entries.theologicalSignificance: דּוֹר teaches that faith is generational. Each generation receives and transmits. God's faithfulness spans all דֹּרוֹת. We are links in a chain from Abraham to eschaton.
entries.ntConnection: From generation to generation (Luke 1:50). Throughout all generations (Eph 3:21). This generation (Matt 24:34). You are a chosen generation (1 Pet 2:9). Ages to come (Eph 2:7).

entries.title: Family/Clan/Nation
entries.summary: מִשְׁפָּחָה is family or clan - the extended kinship group between household and tribe. All families of the earth will be blessed through Abraham. God's blessing extends to all מִשְׁפְּחוֹת.
entries.ancientContext: מִשְׁפָּחָה was the intermediate social unit providing identity, protection, and inheritance. The Abrahamic promise to bless all מִשְׁפְּחוֹת הָאֲדָמָה universalized Israel's particular election.
entries.rootAnalysis: מִשְׁפָּחָה occurs 304 times. Probably from שׁפח (pour out, spread). The clan as extension of family. Levels: בֵּית אָב (father's house), מִשְׁפָּחָה (clan), שֵׁבֶט (tribe), עַם (people).
entries.otUsage: מִשְׁפָּחָה describes: (1) extended family (Gen 10:5), (2) clan (Num 26), (3) nations (Gen 12:3), (4) species (Gen 8:19), (5) social unit for land/worship (Josh 7:14). Blessing's scope.

keyPassages.significance: In you all families of the earth will be blessed.

keyPassages.hebrew: רַק אֶתְכֶם יָדַעְתִּי מִכֹּל מִשְׁפְּחוֹת הָאֲדָמָה
keyPassages.significance: You only have I known of all families of the earth.

keyPassages.hebrew: מִשְׁפְּחוֹת הָאָרֶץ... לְהִשְׁתַּחֲוֹת לְמֶלֶךְ יְהוָה צְבָאוֹת
keyPassages.significance: Families of earth go up to worship the King, YHWH of hosts.

entries.theologicalSignificance: מִשְׁפָּחָה shows that eschatological hope is universal. All families blessed through Abraham. God's kingdom includes every nation, tribe, tongue. Election serves universal blessing.
entries.ntConnection: All nations blessed in Abraham (Gal 3:8). Every family in heaven and earth (Eph 3:15). Every tribe, tongue, people, nation (Rev 5:9). Go make disciples of all nations (Matt 28:19).
